key_points: Tiger Woods was involved in a serious car crash in Los Angeles, causing him serious injuries including open fractures to his legs.
Woods underwent a long surgical procedure on his lower right leg and ankle.
Chief Medical Officer and interim CEO at Harbor-UCLA Medical Centre, Änish Mahajan, provided details on Woods' injuries and surgery.
Injuries included comminuted open fractures to the tibia and fibula, which were stabilized with a rod, screws, and pins.
Woods also underwent surgery to relieve pressure due to swelling in his leg muscles.
After surgery, Woods is reported to be awake, responsive, and recovering in the hospital.
The golfer was alone in the car during the accident, which involved the car rolling several times.
Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva said the car's airbags deployed, providing a cushion that helped Woods survive.
Police found no evidence of alcohol or substances influencing the crash.
Deputy Carlos Gonzalez, the first officer on the scene, highlighted Woods' calmness and the role of his seatbelt in potentially saving his life.
spokespersons: Änish Mahajan (Chief Medical Officer and interim CEO, Harbor-UCLA Medical Centre)
